isis.stitle: Recall 99302 - Brake Mounting Nuts to Rear Axle

recall.subject: Brake Mounting Nuts to Rear Axle

defect.para: This Recall applies to AmTran RE, AmTran FE, and GENESIS buses, and 1652 stripped chassis built from October 16, 1998 through February 9, 1999.

American Transportation Corporation (AmTran) has determined that a defect relating to motor vehicle safety exists in some AmTran RE™, AmTran FE™, GENESIS™ buses, and 1652 stripped chassis. This defect involves the rear brake monting hardware to the rear axle.

Some the units in this recall may have been built with "grade 5" lock nuts instead of "grade 8" lock nuts or a mixture of "grade 5" lock nuts and "grade 8" lock nuts. "Grade 5" lock nuts in this application may strip prior to achieving the specified torque. Improper torque of the fastener or fasteners that retain the brakes to the rear axle may allow brake groups to separate from the rear axle. This defect could cause a vehicular accident without warning which could result in personal injury or property damage, or both.
Owners are being notified of this recall and have been directed to contact an AmTran Alliance dealer to make arrangements for inspection and remedy of the defect.

svcproc.title: INSPECTION
svcproc.para: Inspection of this defect requires the removal and installation of the wheel assemblies, including the brake drum, with air brake equipped units or the rotor with hydraulic equipped units. Caution! Refer to your truck or bus service manual for precautions and instructions to remove tires and rim assemblies, hubs, drums, and brakes. Make sure that all fasteners are reassembled correctly and the correct torque is applied per the service manual instructions. Failure to follow proper procedures for removal of parts could result in personal injury and/or property damage. We strongly suggest that the rear wheel seal be replaced any time that the bearings and hub are removed.

step1.para: Clearly identify each nut that secures the brakes system to the axle, making sure that each one has the correct nut installed. See Figure 3 and Figure 4 to identify location of subject nuts. If any of the nuts do not have the required markings of a "grade 8" lock nut then it must be replaced. See Figure 1 and Figure 2 for identification of the nuts.

svcproc.para: This nut has three (3) markings; one each on every other hex corner. The markings consist of a dot or a combination of dots and a letter. This is the nut that must be replaced.

This nut has six (6) markings; one on every hex corner or on the flat side of the nut. The markings look like dots. The nuts with the markings on the flat side will also have three triangular markings at the top of the nut close to the threaded opening. This style on nut is the correct part and does not need to be replaced.
Typical air brake assembled to the axle showing nuts involved in recall.
Typical hydraulic brake assembled to the axle showing nuts involved in recall.

step1.para: Please complete and return the "AUTHORIZATION FOR RECALL SERVICE" card checking one of the boxes, #1 through #6 that is applicable to the particular unit identified on this card.
Replace the "grade 5" lock nut with the "grade 8" lock nut. Torque nuts to 115 - 125 lb. ft.
Install the "Campaign Identification Label" (see instructions below).
Complete by checking box #2 and return the owners' postage-paid "AUTHORIZATION FOR RECALL SERVICE" card.

partsinfo.para: Cost of purchasing new "grade 8" lock nuts and the cost of the wheel seals should be added to the recall claim.

We are not specifying the wheel seal part number since wheel seals vary in size for the different axles. Refer to your parts manual for your application or use the removed seal for reference. These nuts and seals should be available in your parts department.

entry.para: Retrieval and return of unit and completion of documentation
Inspect units with air brakes and disc wheels
Inspect units with air brakes and cast wheels
Replace mounting nuts at axle flange per side

responuscan.para:
Proceed immediately to make necessary correction to units in inventory. All inventory vehicles subject to this recall campaign must be corrected prior to sale, transfer or delivery.
If vehicles have been sold or transferred and you are in receipt of Customer Notification Letters and Authorization for Recall Service cards for those vehicles, transfer location or customer must be notified from your dealer location.

The National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act, as amended, provides that each vehicle that is subject to a vehicle recall campaign must be adequately repaired within a reasonable time after the owner has tendered it for repair. A failure to adequately repair within 60 days after a tender of a vehicle is prima facie evidence of failure to repair within a reasonable time. If the condition is not adequately repaired within 60 days, the owner may be entitled to replacement with an identical or reasonable equivalent vehicle at no charge, or to a refund of the purchase price less a reasonable allowance for depreciation.

In order to avoid having to replace an owner's vehicle or refund the purchase price, every effort must be made to promptly schedule an appointment with each owner to repair his or her vehicle as soon as possible.
